key_points: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blocks quick Senate impeachment trial for President Donald Trump but does not rule out voting to convict.
House voted 232-197 to impeach Trump, making him the first president to be impeached twice.
McConnell suggests Trump's Senate trial will not start before Jan. 19, a day before Joe Biden's inauguration.
McConnell states a fair trial cannot conclude before Biden takes office, recommends focusing on a safe inauguration.
McConnell has not decided on his vote and plans to listen to the legal arguments during the Senate trial.
McConnell's view of Trump has cooled, potentially influencing other GOP lawmakers to turn against Trump.
McConnell believes Trump committed impeachable offenses and sees impeachment as a chance to distance GOP from Trump.
Senate in recess, McConnell and Schumer did not agree on an emergency session for the trial.
It is unclear how many Republicans would vote to convict Trump, with some GOP senators expressing openness to consider impeachment.
Capitol increases security measures in anticipation of potential further violence by armed Trump supporters.
